variants.name: D30K
variants.protein_change: Aspartic acid to lysine at position 30
variants.functional_evidence: Reduced secretion compared to wild-type UCH-L1
variants.disease_relevance: Associated with impaired UCH-L1 secretion, linked to Parkinson's disease

acmg_steps.description: Disease mechanism defined by UCH-L1 secretion in Parkinson's. D30K variant reduces secretion, directly impacting the mechanism.
Assay (secretion analysis) is applicable to the disease mechanism (secretion in UCH-L1).
Controls (wild-type) and replicates (cultured cell experiments) are present. Variant control (D30K) is used.
No statistical analysis (p-values, etc.), but direct comparison shows reduced secretion. Evidence is supportive.

variants.name: C90S
variants.functional_evidence: No reduction in secretion compared to wild-type UCH-L1
variants.disease_relevance: Lacks hydrolase activity but maintains secretion, suggesting non-pathogenic effect on PD mechanism

acmg_steps.description: Disease mechanism defined by UCH-L1 secretion in Parkinson's. C90S variant maintains secretion, consistent with non-pathogenic role.
Assay (secretion analysis) is applicable to the disease mechanism (secretion in UCH-L1).
Controls (wild-type) and replicates (cultured cell experiments) are present. Variant control (C90S) is used.
No statistical analysis (p-values, etc.), but direct comparison shows normal secretion. Evidence is supportive.

variants.name: I93M
variants.functional_evidence: Reduced secretion compared to wild-type UCH-L1
variants.disease_relevance: Linked to Parkinson's disease via impaired UCH-L1 secretion

acmg_steps.description: Disease mechanism defined by UCH-L1 secretion in Parkinson's. I93M variant reduces secretion, directly impacting the mechanism.
Assay (secretion analysis) is applicable to the disease mechanism (secretion in UCH-L1).
Controls (wild-type) and replicates (cultured cell experiments) are present. Variant control (I93M) is used.
No statistical analysis (p-values, etc.), but direct comparison shows reduced secretion. Evidence is supportive.
